quiz.title: Foundations of Algebra (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: Unit 1 Quiz 1: The Real Number System (10 Questions)
quiz.subject: Mathematics

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a real number?
questions.explanation: √-1 is an imaginary number (represented as i). All other options are real numbers: √4 = 2, -3.5 is rational, π is irrational but real.

questions.question: The number -7 belongs to which sets of numbers?
questions.explanation: -7 is an integer (no fractional part) and also a rational number (can be written as -7/1). It is NOT a whole number or natural number (those start at 0 or 1).

questions.question: Which set of numbers includes all fractions and integers?
questions.explanation: Rational numbers include all numbers that can be written as fractions a/b where b≠0. This includes integers (like 3 = 3/1) and fractions (like ½).

questions.question: π (pi) is classified as:
questions.explanation: π is an irrational number because it cannot be written as a simple fraction. Its decimal representation goes on forever without repeating.

questions.question: Which number is both a whole number and an integer?
questions.explanation: 0 is a whole number (starts at 0) and also an integer (no fractional part). -2 is integer but not whole; 0.5 is neither; √2 is irrational.

questions.question: The set {1, 2, 3, 4, ...} represents:
questions.explanation: Natural numbers are the counting numbers starting from 1: {1, 2, 3, 4, ...}. Whole numbers include 0: {0, 1, 2, 3, ...}.

questions.question: Which statement is TRUE about real numbers?
options: All whole numbers are natural numbers
questions.explanation: Every integer can be written as a fraction (e.g., 5 = 5/1), so all integers are rational numbers. The reverse is not true (½ is rational but not integer).

questions.question: √25 is classified as:
questions.explanation: √25 = 5, which is both a rational number (5/1) and an integer. It's also a whole number and natural number, but 'rational and integer' is most complete.

questions.question: Which number belongs to the MOST subsets of real numbers?
questions.explanation: √9 = 3 belongs to: natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, and rational numbers. -3 misses natural/whole; 0 misses natural; 2.5 is only rational.

questions.question: The Venn diagram of real numbers shows that:
options: Natural numbers are outside whole numbers
Irrational numbers overlap with rational numbers
questions.explanation: Whole numbers {0, 1, 2, ...} are a subset of integers {..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ...}. So whole numbers are 'inside' the integer set in a Venn diagram.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand the real number system hierarchy and can classify numbers accurately.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You grasp the basics but review the relationships between number subsets.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on memorizing: Natural (1,2,3...), Whole (+0), Integers (+negatives), Rational (fractions), Irrational (π, √2).
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember: Real numbers include rational and irrational numbers. Rational numbers include integers, which include whole numbers, which include natural numbers.
